response.answer_text: I have no fear, and because of non-stop news coverage, very little about this virus is unknown. If you subtract the number of people who died as a result of idiotic governmental orders to admit infected patients into nursing and assisted care homes, and also those who were already sick with pre-existing conditions, the death rate of this coronavirus event hardly merits the description of a “pandemic.” I reserve such words for plagues that kill millions, taking at least a quarter of the entire population to their graves. Otherwise, it’s just a minor, middling, or major inconvenience. Covid-19 qualifies as a middling inconvenience, aggravated by a media-induced panic. I am 68, a cancer survivor, and still in uncertain health, yet, I am unafraid. I go shopping regularly to supermarkets, and big box retailers like Costco and Super Walmart. I don’t wear a mask, and I don’t panic if another person comes within 6 feet of me. I may or may not wash my hands after using the restroom, and I touch my goddam face whenever I feel like it. Here in Arizona, we’ve had just over 700 deaths from the virus. However, 140+ were on the Navajo reservation, over 300 were in nursing or assisted living homes, leaving fewer than 300 deaths among the general population of over 7.2 million. Statistically, that’s nothing to get too excited about. And with the coming of our gloriously hot summer and our humid monsoon season, both of which are supposed to be fatal to the virus, the pandemic will dissolve into the mists of history. Gotta go now - restaurants are back open - thanks for asking.

I take one day at a time. I am blessed to have a relatively secure job and I follow a set of coronavirus guidelines, which I have listed below, to protect myself and my family. It doesn’t guarantee that I won’t get sick, but it makes it less likely and gives me a sense of control. I keep busy, watch minimal news and stay off social media other than quora. Keeping up with the daily body count is not particularly useful so I only listen to the news to see if there are any breakthroughs, but I think it is still a little early for that. I find that keeping busy is the best to ignore fear, and it doesn’t matter if you are busy doing or thinking about things to do. As Forrest Gump might have said “My momma always told me that an idle mind is the devil’s workshop”. I find that helping others is a great way to boost myself too. Wear a face covering and eyeglasses (non-prescription if your eyesight is good)When you go out, keep your distance from others. If you are jogging, don’t run right behind anyone elseDon’t stay too long in places where people linger - restroom stalls/sinks, cash registers, etc., because the air there is more likely to have the virusTry to avoid touching surfaces that you don’t need to.If you touch a surface outside your house (or even in your house if you already have a sick person), make sure you don’t touch your eyes or nose for at 30 minutes or until you wash your hands thoroughly. This is an important thing to remember when you bring in your mail, groceries, etc.When you bring in something from outside, you can either (a) leave it alone for a day (if it has a porous covering like paper/cardboard) or 3 days (it has a non-porous covering), or (b) take it out of the covering, dispose of the covering and wash your hands - when you take it out, don’t touch the inside contents with your bare hands. You can use a pair of gloves or small towels that you use for this sole purpose and set them aside after you are done, or you could use a paper towel or something disposable.When you come in from the outside, wipe the doorknobs with a disinfectant because you have to touch them to come inTake vitamin C (1000 mg or more) every day; A multivitamin every day will help you get zinc and vitamin D which are important for immunity.If you take the above, your risks of catching the virus will be highly reducedKeep a stock of zinc based cold lozenges. If you feel the symptoms (dry cough, sore throat, loss of smell or taste), start taking them.If you are at home and are struggling to breathe because of the infection, hospitals have found that laying on your stomach makes it much easier to breathe.

I’m 65. I’ve survived boats capsizing, an airplane crash, car crashes (for awhile there it seemed that everyone wanted to bonk into my car), ski crashes while competing in downhill races, ski crashes while in speed skiing events, fires, cancer surgery, and other stuff that isn’t popping into my mind right now. I don’t fear death. I don’t fear much of anything. So Covid-19 doesn’t bother me much at all. Although while we are alive we have no reason not to assume we mortal, we all know we are going to die. The question is when and maybe how? Death is a waiting game, it makes life interesting. However in actionable terms, assuming suicide is out of the picture, we are spectators to our own demise. My assumption about it then is that it doesn’t really matter when and while we all imagine we are going to die with our family and friends surrounding us, and all is tranquille, and the last thing we see is the gaze of those people and maybe the sun setting on the mountains, that won’t happen. We die alone. Fast or slow it makes no difference in the end. What matters is how we spend our whole lives, not those last few moments when we die. That means understanding risk, and living within our own risk capacity. Uncertainty is a given. There is no way to predict future events. The complexity of our world generally prevents that. We make guesses and hope for the best, but events overtake us constantly. We should think about that, and plan for those weird events such as a epidemic, and have some materials on hand that may help us get through one better than we would without a plan. Other than that, relax and wait.

First, I hope that everyone that will read this is healthy and safe. Now, to be honest, I fear more for the elderly people that I care about (grandparents (father’s side), neighbours…), than I fear for myself. I am 20 years old and I practically don’t leave my house since 13 of March, I only opened a few exceptions (taking walks int the forest to clear my mind and visiting my boyfriend since he got surgery, I only see him once a week and besides, he doesn’t leave the house much either…). I actually don’t fear much for myself because I avoid leaving the house, and I wash my hands regularly. I am more afraid of the consequences of the actions caused by the simple mentality and thoughts of the mid-age and younger generations. My country, Portugal, is already returning back to normal, although I believe is still too soon (we were told that 300 people got infected just yesterday) and people are visiting cafes, go to the beach and don’t care anymore… This following weeks I have been hearing my father saying this: “Okay, we are not elderly so even if we catch it it wouldn’t be that much serious. It doesn’t affect mid-aged or younger people that much.” By this, you can see that he has no clue of what happens with your body if you contract COVID-19. My parents don’t understand how the transmission chain works either, after all, you can’t control what the other people touch, and their health habits. Yet, my parents don’t mind going, sitting in the cafes, touching things… My fear? My grandfather’s health, since we live next to each other and my parents have contact with him every day. By their everyday actions, I have seen that they are not very considerate about my grandfather’s health. On the mother’s side of the family things aren’t good either. They all were so immature that in the middle of the chaos they organized a birthday party for my grandmother, and all the family went! Note: the family add a fight in the past so, only me and my sister were supposed to go to the party (since my parents are not talking much to my mother’s sibling). Both me and my sister knew that going wasn’t an option for us, we didn’t want to risk our healths, or put another’s life at risk. The funny part was that my parents were playing mentality games at me and my sister to force us to go there (just to cause a good impression). Something like: “oh, go there, everyone will be there except you two and they will think bad of us if you don’t show up” and “you felt bad when your grandparents (mother side) missed your birthdays during all of your childhood, and now she will feel bad if you don’t go there too”. Eventually, we didn’t go, because: The number of people there would be around 20 and the house is very small.We actually don’t have many connections with the mother’s side of the family so we always feel excluded, plus since we are the only grandchildren who are in the university my grandmother always tries to show us off to their neighbours (something that I don’t like).My grandparents are elderly and although I don’t like them much I didn’t want to take a risk.University online exams were coming and coming fast.But, we called her to give her a happy birthday though. Now, to my surprise, two weeks later, my mother gets a call saying that one of her sister’s neighbours was infected. And that sister and their family contacted the infected person and they all went to the birthday party. And that sister didn’t do the test and wasn’t even willing too. Now, imagine the risk that me and my sister could have been exposed too just to satisfy my parent's ego when it comes to family image (that is their life priority, trust me, and I have more stories about it that I am willing to share if the readers want). Anyways, we eventually fought about the matter, to make them understand the consequences that could have become a reality if we went there. But no matter how many times we fight about it, they never truly understand, because it’s a question of mentality. Note: Even on the father’s side the family image issue remains, since my oldest uncle and my dad have that siblings rivalry were one always wants to surpass the other. They brought their life achievements into the rivalry and even their kids became a part of it (they even lied about me to everyone which is sad). I would be happy to get some comments with your honest opinions and advices.

It is not as difficult for me as it might be for others. In a sense, I feel as though I’ve been expecting something like this most of my life. I am 68. I have worked for just over 50 years and made good pay, so my Social Security is generous, though not enough to cover my expenses. I still have to work to meet my financial goals. I am unemployed, but when I work, I am well paid. That also means that I can draw the top unemployment benefit, which is quite generous in my state. And I had money saved up. All this means I can survive for not quite 6 months after my last job ended, which is something few can say. I am in good health, and if something happens, I am on Medicare and have an excellent Medicare Advantage policy from a well known insurer. The only prescription medicine I am on is a generic that costs just $12 for a 3-month supply. The nature of my work is such that I can work from home, if the client allows it. I have to do so many work searches a week to qualify for unemployment, though I usually get no response or acknowledgment whatsoever from those online applications. I get many phone calls from recruiters, though I can’t understand anything they are saying except “Michael” and “technical writer.” What usually happens is that a recruiter calls at just the right time, and something falls into my lap from outer space. I have literally been contacted by a recruiter on a Friday morning and found myself put to work in the client’s office the following Monday morning. I order everything, including groceries, delivered to my door, and when the delivery person arrives, I stand several feet away or simply let them leave the package and go on before I open the door at all. I leave my apartment just once a day to walk 5 miles for exercise. I have not been in an enclosed space with others since March 18. I ordered a set of men’s hair clippers and cut my own hair, though I couldn’t figure out how to attach the comb attachment, so I had to shave myself bald, and I now look like Mr. Clean. I am symptom-free. I have ordered something advertised as a military-grade respirator, but it hasn’t arrived yet. I had to cancel a paid-up and nonrefundable trip to a European city, planned for May, to visit my son and daughter-in-law and even lost out on a job opportunity because they couldn’t work with that gap in my schedule—ironically, I realized only a week later that the trip would not be possible. I’m sorry all that happened, but in the light of the spread of COVID-19, canceling the trip was necessary. In early March, I bought about 30 rolls of toilet paper, though not all at once. Since I am on a high-fiber diet, a single roll of toilet paper lasts me a little over a week. At the rate I’m going, I can last until Columbus Day. I have ordered multiple rolls of paper towels from Amazon, though shipping is slow, and it may not arrive for a few weeks. I had met with an attorney in February to draw up a new will, power of attorney, etc., but the attorney had to close her office, because her county was put on lockdown (now, so is mine), so I can’t get the documents witnessed or notarized. However, she held a class on Zoom for any clients who were interested, to write a holographic will, which is valid in my state. My children are in their 30s. My daughter is living with her mother 700 miles away in another state, and we will be catching up by phone tomorrow evening. My son and his wife are in Europe. They were in a country where the infection rate and death toll were climbing quite rapidly, but they were able to get back to her native country where the count is quite low and are nicely set up in an apartment owned by her parents. I Skype with them about every 3 weeks. I have no grandchildren. My apartment suits me better than just about any place I’ve ever lived. My living-dining area is about 20 feet long and 17 feet wide, with 10-foot ceilings. I have eight bookcases set up there and my 65″ wall-mounted TV. I have a spacious patio-balcony. I can literally be in my apartment all day and not go out at all, though that seldom happens, and I do not feel uncomfortably confined. Although I now realize there is no scientific basis to Myers-Briggs personality types, I still find INTJ a useful shorthand for a cluster of traits that I believe are true of my makeup. It means that I have spent much of my life feeling as though I were in a dark room full of an unruly crowd of people who were wailing, cursing, kicking, punching, and eye-gouging, and I was the only one with night vision goggles. It also means that I always try to figure out what is going on and look ahead. After hearing about environmental pollution in junior high school, I remember dreaming one night that a noxious cloud of smog had reached my part of the country and was covering everything with a brown haze, and as I choked and gasped, I thought “Oh, no, it’s finally happened!” By around February 5, when the total number of COVID-19 cases in the world numbered only in the hundreds, I was already sitting down drafting quite detailed instructions to my kids about what to do if anything happened to me. I met with the attorney in February and told my son that this whole thing put my planned European trip at risk. I did this not having any idea how rapidly the disease would spread. But I knew two persistent strains in American culture: Disdain for getting details right, which is how the CDC distributed a defective test.Locking the barn door after the horse is stolen, which is why we have to take our shoes off at airports.I have thought most of my life that a very large part of humanity were screwups, blundering through life in a daze, knocking things over and then demanding to know who was responsible, vaguely sensing their folly and resenting anyone who saw it with a clear eye, and ready to congratulate themselves for their ignorance. We see all that in who we have elected President and the fanatical support of his base. When I realized Trump was going to win the Republican nomination, I googled “move to Canada.” But Canada has quite strict financial requirements, and I don’t qualify. When he was elected, I briefly considered leaping to my death from my balcony, but didn’t wish to distress my kids. COVID, to me, is just one more layer of icing on the cake we baked when we elected Drumpf. He didn’t invent it, but he is responsible for making the outcome worse and is working even now to expose more of his own citizens, whether he realizes it or not. As I commented on another thread, for a head of state to actively support measures whose likely outcome is to cause more of his own citizens to sicken and die is a situation without precedent, as far as I know, in human history. No, I didn’t know I was going to find myself in a worldwide pandemic, but I already witnessed, first-hand, the conditions that could lead to this over 20 years ago when I spent three weeks in the hospital after a serious automobile accident and found myself having to act like an air traffic controller because so many doctors, nurses, and orderlies kept screwing up, because their minds weren’t on their work. Many people just don’t pay attention. And they get pissed if you point it out to them. People like that elected our President. He was already the most dangerous man in the world by virtue of his access to nuclear codes, but his position of authority in the time of a pandemic is, in its own way, infinitely worse. So if someone asks how I will deal with the uncertainty, I think “What uncertainty? This was always one possible outcome, though, admittedly an extreme one.” There is an episode of Black Mirror in which some people break into a warehouse and alert a robotic watchdog, who relentlessly pursues them. There is little or no chance of evading it. If it gets near enough to you, it will either do something to cause your head to explode, or it will spit small fragments of glass that will lodge in your throat too close to your jugular to be removed without causing you to bleed to death anyway. I have sometimes felt as though I were being pursued by that dog. The people on whose behalf it prowls around were too dim to have invented such a thing, but it serves their purposes perfectly. That is life in a high-tech society in the time of Trump. Or as I commented in another thread, like the aftermath of the Great Chicago Fire: a once-great city destroyed because a dumb animal in a barn kicked over a lantern, and now, there are mainly smoking ruins and nothing left but to begin rebuilding. I don’t dwell much on the fear and uncertainty, because my personal circumstances let me live in some degree of safety and comfort, because my friends, most of whom I am in touch with via Facebook, all seem to be surviving, and because I am convinced that my children are as safe and secure as they can be under the circumstances. What will happen to me? Will I get a job before my money runs out? Who knows? Will I ever see my kids again? It is logically possible that I may not. But past a certain point, I refuse to let myself be troubled too much by something that I have known, since childhood, could be a possibility, by virtue of the ignorance and folly of so much of humanity and, in particular, the anti-intellectualism and disdain for learning of so many of my fellow countrymen.

COPING UP WITH INEVITABLE CHALLANGES DURING COVID-19 PANDEMIC The spread of coronavirus has disrupted lives of many people across the globe on their mental and physical health. We all are going through rough patch. Everyone is suffering some kind of mental agony be it’s a child, young generation or elder people . As we remain confined within our houses, we tend to get more use to televisions, mobile phones, internet which is leading us to consume more and more news, rumors and misinformation as media has lot of undesirable and unwanted news (LOL). No outdoor activities, financial stress, job loss. All these abrupt changes has widely contributed to mental and physical trauma (combined with fear of getting infected or losing loved ones). Now it’s safe to say that we are experiencing one of the most uncertain times in history. But if we keep feeding our brain with everything that can go wrong, things can be worse for our mental health. This year will go down in history as one of the downs. Time passes and this shall too pass since TOUGH TIMES NEVER LAST, TOUGH PEOPLE DO. What matters entirely is to choose our attitude towards such hurdles. If we are constantly aware and preparing ourselves for each of the uncertainty and bad events we can prevent us from such fear and anxiety. If we analyze, some people tolerate such uncertainties without any stress and continue living in an easy going manner while others find such challenges to be distressing. Why? How do they cope up? They believe on words spoken by Charles R. Swindoll - Life is 10% of what happens to us and 90% of how we react to it. Let me elaborate the above words: Unpredictable events will occur, uncomfortable experiences will come into our life as most of the things are out of our control such as natural disasters, viruses, diseases, other people reactions, behaviour etc. What here we can do is to control our actions and reactions. Anticipating future will just keep us more and more stress in present. “Worry does not empty tomorrow of its sorrow, it empties today of its strength.”― Corrie Ten Boom Now, another question that will pop up in readers mind is, how do we control that? We need to think that how we are spending our time, where we are putting our efforts and energy into. In such challenging times, we need to shift our focus to things or actions that can help in solving our problems because we don’t know what the future holds. However, we can prepare for some serious outcomes by creating an action plan. There is also a special report in Time magazine that best way to reduce stress is by ‘’fighting stress before it even starts, planning things rather than letting them happen.’’ For example, if you are stress about the financial crunch, create a plan to earn more through different sources, cutting variable expenses, saving more and investing some of the saving into low risk opportunities. If you are worried about the work load responsibilities, share the work load with the family members. Involve your children into household activities and teaching them learn new things. Have trust. They will enjoy! Similarly, if you are worried about the physical health, adopt some self-care techniques at home. Be fun, be creative, but whatever you do, do it for yourself because you deserve it. There is much much content about how to do simple workout at home to cut your body fat and keep it fit. Try to take those actions which can be helpful in improving your personal relationships, career, finances and others. There is always something which we have control on. It’s time to take pro-active steps to support your mental health during these unprecedented times. Don’t limit your efforts and energy into things which will keep your more distress and exhausted. With patience we all will be able to build the tolerance power to such uncertainties, control over emotions and eventually building mental strength.
